div1.p: Clemons will fulfill Hench's request to have items photographed and mailed to Lyons.

div1.head: Letter from Harry Clemons to Philip Showalter Hench, March 25, 1948
div1.opener:
UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
CHARLOTTESVILLE
ALDERMAN LIBRARY
25 March 1948
OFFICE OF THE LIBRARIAN
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
We have received your letter of March
twentieth, with a copy of a letter to Miss Bertha L. Lyons
enclosed. Mr. Berkeley, Curator of Manuscripts, is giving
personal attention to the carrying out of your requests.

The seven items indicated in that letter are be-
ing photographed in our photographic laboratory. There
is some doubt as to whether our equipment will be success-
ful with items, four, five, six, and seven. If not, Mr.
Berkeley will take those four to our Medical Department
Photographer, and will remain with them until the photo-
graphing has been completed. The reproductions will then
be mailed to Miss Lyons, with notice to her and to you.

We shall be glad to have a visit from you about
May tenth -- or anytime! But if we have word from you
that at the International Congress on Tropical Medicine in
Washington they want your material before May tenth, we
can have it securely wrapped and forwarded to you by
insured express.

We congratulate the International Congress on
having you as its principal speaker for the Walter Reed
memorial evening. We have heard you speak and we know
how fortunate they are. We also congratulate you on the
opportunities afforded by these Walter Reed memorials in
Washington and New York.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Harry Clemons
Librarian To Dr. Philip S. Hench
102-110 Second Avenue, S. W.
Rochester, Minnesota
